name: npm-developer-expert
description: Comprehensive npm (Node Package Manager) expert covering package management, package.json, semantic versioning, npm scripts, workspaces, npx, scoped packages, private registries, publishing, security auditing, and npm ecosystem best practices

sources.version_info: npm (Node Package Manager) - latest stable version

can_do: Explain npm install commands and flags
Explain semantic versioning (semver) and version ranges
Demonstrate npm workspace setup for monorepos
Show npx usage for running packages
Configure scoped packages and private registries
Show npm link for local development
cannot_do: Choose package versions (depends on project requirements)
Suggest package names (must be available and follow naming rules)

what_is_npm.statement: npm (Node Package Manager) is the default package manager for Node.js and the world's largest software registry. npm consists of three components: the website (npmjs.com), the Command Line Interface (CLI), and the registry. npm enables sharing and reusing JavaScript code.
what_is_npm.example: npm manages JavaScript packages, their dependencies, and provides tools for package installation, publishing, and versioning

npm_components.statement: npm consists of: (1) npm registry - public registry hosting millions of packages, (2) npm CLI - command-line tool for interacting with npm, (3) npm website - web interface for browsing packages and managing accounts.
npm_components.example: npm install express uses npm CLI to download express package from npm registry

structure.statement: package.json is the manifest file for npm packages. Required fields: name (package name, lowercase, no spaces, can use scopes like @company/package), version (semantic version x.y.z). Important fields: description, main (entry point), scripts, dependencies, devDependencies, keywords, author, license, repository, bugs, homepage.

dependency_types.statement: package.json has multiple dependency types: dependencies (runtime dependencies required for package to run), devDependencies (development dependencies, not installed in production), peerDependencies (expected host dependencies, user must install), optionalDependencies (optional, failures don't break install), bundledDependencies (bundled with package).

files_field.statement: files field in package.json specifies which files to include in published package (whitelist). .npmignore file (like .gitignore) specifies files to exclude (blacklist). If files not specified, package includes all files except those in .npmignore or default ignores.
files_field.example: "files": ["lib", "README.md", "LICENSE"] includes only lib directory, README, and LICENSE in published package

local_installation.statement: npm install <package-name> installs package locally in node_modules folder. Adds entry to dependencies in package.json. Use --save-dev or -D flag to add to devDependencies instead.
local_installation.example: npm install express --save installs express and adds to dependencies. npm install jest --save-dev adds to devDependencies

global_installation.statement: npm install -g <package-name> installs package globally (accessible from command line). Global packages are typically CLI tools. Global install location varies by OS.
global_installation.example: npm install -g typescript installs TypeScript compiler globally, making tsc command available system-wide

version_specification.statement: npm install supports version specification: npm install <package>@<version> (specific version), npm install <package>@latest (latest version), npm install <package>@^4.18.0 (version range).
version_specification.example: npm install express@4.18.2 installs exact version. npm install express@^4.18.0 installs compatible 4.x version

package_lock.statement: package-lock.json locks exact dependency versions for reproducible installs. Automatically generated on npm install. Should be committed to version control. Locked versions take precedence over package.json version ranges.
package_lock.example: Running npm install uses package-lock.json to install exact same versions across different machines and environments

semver_format.statement: Semantic versioning (semver) uses MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH format. MAJOR version for breaking changes (incompatible API), MINOR version for new features (backward compatible), PATCH version for bug fixes (backward compatible).
semver_format.example: 1.0.0 (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH). Breaking change: 2.0.0. New feature: 1.1.0. Bug fix: 1.0.1

version_ranges.statement: npm supports version ranges: ^4.18.0 (compatible with 4.x, >=4.18.0 <5.0.0, allows MINOR and PATCH updates), ~4.17.21 (compatible with 4.17.x, >=4.17.21 <4.18.0, allows only PATCH updates), 4.18.0 (exact version), >=3.0.0 <4.0.0 (range), * (any version).

npm_run.statement: npm run <script-name> executes scripts defined in package.json scripts field. npm start, npm test, npm stop have shortcuts (can run without 'run'). Scripts run in node_modules/.bin in PATH.
npm_run.example: "scripts": {"start": "node server.js", "test": "jest"} can be run with npm start and npm test

lifecycle_scripts.statement: npm lifecycle scripts run automatically: prepublishOnly (before npm publish), preinstall/postinstall (before/after install), prepack/postpack (before/after tarball creation), prepublishOnly (before publish only, not before npm install).
lifecycle_scripts.example: "scripts": {"prepublishOnly": "npm test && npm run build"} runs tests and build before publishing

script_precedence.statement: Scripts with 'pre' and 'post' prefixes run automatically: pre<name> runs before <name>, post<name> runs after <name>. Example: pretest runs before test, posttest runs after test.
script_precedence.example: "pretest": "echo 'before test'", "test": "jest", "posttest": "echo 'after test'" runs pretest, test, posttest in sequence

workspace_setup.statement: npm workspaces (npm 7+) allow managing multiple packages in monorepo. Define workspaces array in root package.json. All workspace packages share single node_modules at root with hoisted dependencies.
workspace_setup.example: "workspaces": ["packages/*", "apps/*"] manages all packages in packages/ and apps/ directories

workspace_commands.statement: npm commands support --workspaces flag to run across all workspaces, or --workspace=<name> to run in specific workspace. npm install installs dependencies for all workspaces.
workspace_commands.example: npm run test --workspaces runs test script in all workspaces. npm run build --workspace=packages/core runs build only in packages/core

npx_usage.statement: npx (npm package executor) runs packages without installing globally. Downloads package if not found, runs it, then deletes. Useful for one-time commands and trying packages without permanent install.
npx_usage.example: npx create-react-app my-app runs create-react-app without installing globally. npx jest runs jest from node_modules if installed locally

npx_execution.statement: npx searches for executable: (1) local node_modules/.bin, (2) installed globally, (3) downloads temporarily if not found. Can execute local scripts with npx ./script.js.
npx_execution.example: npx eslint . runs eslint from local node_modules. npx -p <package> <command> ensures package is available before running command

publish_process.statement: npm publish publishes package to npm registry. Requires: (1) npm login to authenticate, (2) package.json with name and version, (3) valid package structure. Publishes to current registry (public or private).
publish_process.example: npm login then npm publish publishes package to npm registry with version from package.json

publish_tags.statement: npm publish --tag <tag> publishes with specific tag. Default tag is 'latest'. Tags allow multiple versions: npm publish --tag beta publishes as beta tag, users install with npm install <package>@beta.
publish_tags.example: npm publish --tag beta publishes version as beta tag. npm install my-package@beta installs beta version

unpublish.statement: npm unpublish <package-name>@<version> removes package version from registry. Can only unpublish within 72 hours of publishing unless using --force (requires support interaction).
unpublish.example: npm unpublish my-package@1.0.0 removes version 1.0.0 from registry (within 72 hours)

npm_version.statement: npm version patch/minor/major bumps version in package.json and creates git tag. npm version patch (1.0.0 -> 1.0.1), npm version minor (1.0.0 -> 1.1.0), npm version major (1.0.0 -> 2.0.0).
npm_version.example: npm version patch bumps patch version, commits package.json, creates git tag v1.0.1

version_flags.statement: npm version supports flags: -m "message" (commit message), --no-git-tag-version (skip git tag), --preid (prerelease identifier for prerelease versions).
version_flags.example: npm version patch -m "Version %s" creates commit with message 'Version 1.0.1'

scope_syntax.statement: Scoped packages use @scope/package-name syntax. Scopes are typically organization names. Scoped packages can be public or private. Publishing requires --access public for public scoped packages (or configuring in package.json).
scope_syntax.example: @mycompany/utils is scoped package. npm publish --access public publishes public scoped package

scope_registry.statement: Scoped packages can use different registries per scope. Configure with npm config set @scope:registry <url>. Allows mixing public npm registry with private registries.
scope_registry.example: npm config set @mycompany:registry https://npm.pkg.github.com/ makes @mycompany packages install from GitHub Packages

registry_types.statement: npm supports private registries: npm organizations (built-in private packages), self-hosted (npm Enterprise), third-party (GitHub Packages, Azure Artifacts, JFrog Artifactory). Configure with .npmrc or npm config.
registry_types.example: Private packages on npm require paid subscription. GitHub Packages provides private packages with GitHub integration

npm_organizations.statement: npm organizations provide team management, private scoped packages, unified billing, and permissions control. Members can publish packages under organization scope.
npm_organizations.example: @myorg/package can be private package accessible only to organization members

npm_audit.statement: npm audit scans dependencies for known vulnerabilities. npm audit shows vulnerabilities, npm audit fix automatically fixes non-breaking vulnerabilities, npm audit fix --force attempts breaking changes (use carefully).
npm_audit.example: npm audit lists vulnerabilities. npm audit fix updates packages to fix vulnerabilities without breaking changes

audit_reports.statement: npm audit provides vulnerability reports with severity (low, moderate, high, critical), package affected, vulnerability description, and recommended fix.
audit_reports.example: npm audit shows: Package: lodash, Vulnerability: Prototype Pollution, Severity: High, Recommendation: Update to 4.17.21+

npmrc_files.statement: npm configuration uses .npmrc files in priority order: (1) project .npmrc, (2) user .npmrc (~/.npmrc), (3) global .npmrc, (4) npm's built-in .npmrc. Settings in higher priority override lower priority.

config_commands.statement: npm config set <key> <value> sets configuration. npm config get <key> reads configuration. npm config list shows all configuration. npm config edit opens .npmrc in editor.
config_commands.example: npm config set registry https://registry.npmjs.org/. npm config set save-exact true

environment_variables.statement: npm recognizes NPM_CONFIG_* environment variables. NODE_ENV affects npm behavior (production mode skips devDependencies).
environment_variables.example: NPM_CONFIG_REGISTRY=https://custom.registry.com npm install uses custom registry from environment variable

cache_management.statement: npm cache stores downloaded packages. npm cache clean --force clears cache. npm cache verify checks cache integrity. Cache location: npm config get cache.
cache_management.example: npm cache clean --force clears all cached packages. Useful for troubleshooting installation issues

list_packages.statement: npm list shows installed packages and their dependency tree. npm list --depth=0 shows only top-level packages. npm list -g shows globally installed packages.
list_packages.example: npm list displays dependency tree. npm list express shows express and its dependencies

outdated_packages.statement: npm outdated shows packages with newer versions available. Compares installed versions with versions in package.json ranges and latest versions in registry.
outdated_packages.example: npm outdated shows: Package: express, Current: 4.18.0, Wanted: 4.18.2, Latest: 4.19.0

update_packages.statement: npm update updates packages within version ranges in package.json. npm install <package>@latest installs latest version. Updates package-lock.json with new versions.
update_packages.example: npm update updates all packages to latest compatible versions. npm install express@latest installs latest express version regardless of range

uninstall.statement: npm uninstall <package-name> removes package from node_modules and package.json. Use --save or --save-dev to specify dependency type removal.
uninstall.example: npm uninstall express removes express from node_modules and dependencies. npm uninstall jest --save-dev removes from devDependencies

linking_packages.statement: npm link creates symlink for local package development. In package directory: npm link creates global link. In consuming project: npm link <package-name> links local package. npm unlink removes link.
linking_packages.example: cd my-package && npm link, then cd ../my-app && npm link my-package allows testing my-package changes in my-app without publishing

search_commands.statement: npm search <query> searches npm registry. npm view <package-name> shows package information. npm view <package-name> versions shows all versions. npm view <package-name> readme shows README.
search_commands.example: npm search react router finds packages matching query. npm view express shows express package details

npm_pack.statement: npm pack creates tarball (.tgz file) of package. npm pack --dry-run shows what would be included without creating file. Useful for testing package contents before publishing.
npm_pack.example: npm pack creates my-package-1.0.0.tgz. npm install ./my-package-1.0.0.tgz installs from tarball
